text: Yeah, that was pretty funny. And especially after the fact. Interestingly enough, there were a couple of interesting components to leaving AQR just before the vol blow up. So my understanding, having spoken to some people outside of AQR, is they didn't understand that I left before the vol blow up and they had assumed I left because of the vol blow up. Not true. I left before the vol blow up. So that's point one. Point two is we were very careful about portfolio construction in vol strategies. And one of the considerations that we had when we constructed portfolios is understanding the tail risk of individual positions, having a tail risk budget, sizing positions according to that tail risk budget. And also because vol strategies at AQR really did start from the hedge fund framework and had this notion of tactical views and relative value views, we were incorporating some of those views into our portfolio. And so we were able to do that. And so I think that's a really good So when you include a portfolio construction eye towards tail risk management and some tactical positioning, I think AQR actually came out relatively unscathed in that vol blow up, especially relative to some of the other more newsworthy organizations.
